title: Preview: Spirit Week Themes
content: [caption id="attachment_43149" align="alignnone" width="614"] The Class of 2015 cheers on its peers during the sophomore spirit dance. [Photo: Cathy Rong] [/caption]  Can the firefighting Class of 2019 extinguish the junior fighting spirit? Will the freshman earn their stripes? Or will it be "Game Over" for everyone? With Spirit Week just around the corner, each Palo Alto High School class is eagerly preparing for the most passionate week of the school year. As always, the freshmen, sophomores, juniors and seniors will be represented by their class colors: orange, red, yellow and green, respectively. For its last Spirit Week at Paly, the senior Class of 2017 has gone with the theme of “Game Over.” According to senior Tanner Newell, the Class of 2017 has the potential to do better than previous years. “I think a lot of people are much more engaged this year so we should do better than we’ve ever done before,” Newell said. After much deliberation, the junior class  decided on "boxing" as its theme. There was a bit of controversy over choosing boxing as the theme, as the class originally voted for a different idea. According to junior Sabrina Hall, Spirit Week should be about class unity, not infighting. “I think that the people sort of forgot what Spirit Week is supposed to be about,” Hall said. “It's being united as one grade and all just enjoying this week as a sign of just love for the school and love for the class.” The Class of 2019 is coming into Spirit Week with more confidence than last year and is planning to redeem themselves after coming last during their freshman year with the theme of “firefighters.” “I think the theme is pretty nice," sophomore Paul Shand said. "I think freshmen are going to come last, but I hope we do great.” The freshman class  will be kicking off its first Spirit Week with the theme, “Eye of the Tiger.” Freshman Sarah O’Riordan is excited for the theme. “The freshman theme is so awesome this year,” O'Riordan said. “I can’t wait to see how everyone looks during Spirit Week.”
excerpt: Can the firefighting Class of 2019 extinguish the junior fighting spirit? Will the freshman earn their stripes? Or will it be "Game Over" for everyone?
author: Katie Cox

title: Guide to school board elections: Melissa Baten Caswell
content: [caption id="attachment_122810" align="alignleft" width="436"] Melissa Baten Caswell, who has completed two terms on the school board, acknowledged areas of improvement and strengths of the current school board during the school board forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] The Paly Voice attended the first school board forum hosting all five candidates for the upcoming election. Each candidate hoped to distinguish him or herself from the group, discussing bold ideas while acknowledging problems faced by the district. Read on to take an in-depth look at the various candidates and their platforms. Melissa Baten Caswell, a current school board member, is running for her third term. Caswell has previously served as board president and has experience serving on various school specific PTA councils. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community center, Caswell said she believes in the importance of making sure all Palo Alto Unified School District students are lifelong learners with skills that are relevant in the current and future economy. “We have to make sure every single student is engaged in the classroom and supported, in academics and social emotional health,” Caswell said. “Promote life long learners [that are] engaged in their education. We need to be looking at the whole child, looking at every single student.” In addition, Caswell recounted the various improvements and new additions to curriculum that have taken place during her time on the school board. She noted that an area of improvement is allowing teachers to lead these breakthroughs by providing adequate resources and opportunities. “We have added flipped classrooms, blended learning, pathways [and] we put in a program with 200 students doing research projects,” Caswell said. “I do think one action is to help our teachers with innovative ideas and flushing them out. Give them some time. If we don't give teachers time to focus on innovative ideas they can't do it. Help teachers invest in choice.” Caswell provided further explanations for her past stance against the opening of a new elementary school by noting the amount of classrooms that aren’t used for core classes. “There has been declining enrollment for 5-6 years, it's expensive to have a school,” Caswell said.  “Twenty six classrooms are not being used as primary classrooms in elementary schools." She addressed student-teacher ratios by stating that its importance varies based on the type of class and the teaching style of the instructor. “The quality of the teacher preempts everything,” Caswell said. “I think it would be a good idea for us to have ranges for class size. When we talk about averages it's across the school or department, I think putting hard caps would be difficult.” Caswell highlighted that the district’s previous homework policy should be reevaluated. As it is currently written the board has set a limit on the amount of hours a student should be spending per week on homework, however she stated that the policy isn’t always applicable to all classes or students. “The homework policy is really tough, I think we have some thinking to do about what really should be the policy,” Caswell said. “I don't think a hard cap on minutes works in an environment where students complete work differently. Results have not been brought back to the board and It's hard for teachers to use the policy as it currently is.” Mental health and wellness has always been a vital topic in the Palo Alto community, and Caswell expressed her search for an improved system of assistance while acknowledging the district’s limitations. “Our mission is education of our students and we will never be excellent mental health service providers,” Caswell said. “I look for new models in our community, I am looking to Stanford and other experts. This is a regional issue, state issue and we should work together with our colleagues in the city and state wide.” In light of recent events at Palo Alto High School, student journalists brought to light questions regarding the behavioral conduct among students and teachers. Caswell repeatedly emphasized the importance of an accessible and understandable policy. “It [sexual assault] is incredibly serious and we need to make sure what policy is written down is clear and understandable,” Caswell said. “If everyone understands expectations then it's clear when they've been crossed. It is important that our teachers can be supportive of our students.” Take a look at an introduction to the other candidates and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. Overview of all candidates Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera Todd Collins Jennifer DiBrienza Heidi Emberling
excerpt: Melissa Baten Caswell, a current school board member, is running for her third term. Caswell said she believes in the importance of making sure all PAUSD students are lifelong learners with skills that are relevant in the current and future economy.
author: Daniel Li

title: Guide to school board elections: Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera
content: [caption id="attachment_122797" align="alignright" width="384"] Jacob Cabrera is one of five candidates running for school board. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center, he explained his thoughts on current issues and innovations relating to education in Palo Alto. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] The Paly Voice attended the first school board forum hosting all five candidates for the upcoming election. Each candidate hoped to distinguish him or herself from the group, discussing bold ideas while acknowledging problems faced by the district. Read on to take an in-depth look at the various candidates and their platforms. Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera, a community organizer, is one of five candidates for the upcoming school board election. Having unsuccessfully run for the Board of Education in the 2014 election, Cabrera hopes to gain support for his unique propositions. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center, he emphasized the need for equipping all students with 21st century skills that allow them to reach their full potential. Cabrera said he hopes to engage youth in civic matters by lowering the voting age to 15. He expressed the need for relevant life skills and aims to create an educational system that caters to the unique qualities of each individual student. “Schools should be cultural epicenters of innovation,” Cabrera said. “We should be empowering our youth, and getting youth engaged in society early, transforming the way they interact.” Cabrera’s innovative ideas include integration between elementary and secondary schools. In addition, he says he believes core class sizes ideally should not exceed 20 students. “Integration between elementary, middle and high schools of multiple different ages and types of education in the same space is healthy and a new dynamic,” Cabrera said. “Class size matters a lot, it should be under 20 students. University style lectures in the high schools where they then break out into smaller groups could be effective.” Though he said he wishes to reduce class sizes overall, Cabrera strayed away from providing a hard cap on the number of students enrolled in a class. Over the past few years student complaints have increased in regards to the amount of homework assigned at the secondary level. In addition parents and students have brought up the issue of "test stacking". Many students have multiple tests in core subjects on the same day and sitting through two or three consecutive 90 minute blocks of testing can be grueling. Cabrera believes that to solve the homework and test staking problem in the school district, it is necessary to have at least one year of research and collection of data on the specific topics mentioned above. "I wouldn't be comfortable [discussing solutions] until talking to students and teachers,” Cabrera said. “My interaction with students has been that homework is increasing, and we should reduce in general the amount of homework for free time with families.” According to Cabrera, although mental health is one of the most prominent issues in the community, there is yet to be a solution. “We need to be preemptively active in solving our issues, we need to recognize that we don't have the solutions,” Cabrera said. “The real issues are the societal pressures.” Take a look at an introduction to the other candidates and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. Overview of all candidates Melissa Baten Caswell Todd Collins Jennifer DiBrienza Heidi Emberling
excerpt: Cabrera Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera, a community organizer, is one of five candidates for the upcoming school board election. He emphasized the need for equipping all students with 21st century skills that allow them to reach their full potential.
author: Daniel Li

title: School board candidates vie for three opening seats
content: [caption id="attachment_122786" align="alignnone" width="594"] All five Palo Alto Board of Education candidates pose for a photo together while preparing for the first forum of the 2016 election cycle on Sept. 20. The forum took place at the Mitchell Community Center and was live streamed by Palo Alto Online. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] With less than 40 days remaining until election day on Nov. 8, five candidates for the Palo Alto school board are campaigning in hopes of gaining one of the three opening seats. Two of the five candidates are running for re-election — Heidi Emberling and Melissa Baten Caswell — while the other three candidates include Jay Cabrera, Todd Collins and Jennifer DiBrienza. The third elected member will replace Camille Townsend, a board member since 2008. The newly elected members will serve on the school board for the next four years. As the community currently faces multi-faceted issues, including the budget deficit, the conduct of teachers on campus and the continued anticipation over the coming Epi-Aid final report, candidates will play a major role in decisions that will affect the Palo Alto Unified School District for years to come. Each candidate brings a unique set of experiences from his or her professional life. Emberling serves as the current president of the school board and if elected would be returning for her second term in office. She also serves as a teacher and parent educator at Parents Place, an early child development and learning resource center. Caswell, the most experienced of the group, would be returning for her third term. She has previously served as board president and is experienced in strategy, finance and high tech marketing. Collins and Dibrienza have experience working closely with the district, while Cabrera is a Gunn High School alumnus. Collins is a private investor and has served on the citizens’ oversight committee of a school bond program and the school board’s Enrollment Management Advisory Committee over the 2015-16 school year. Dibrienza was a teacher and staff developer for primary education before switching to become an educational consultant and has served on Ohlone Elementary School’s site council. Cabrera, a community organizer, currently works as chief executive officer of Unity Network. According to its website, Unity Network is a nonprofit that aims to solve 21st century problems through innovative methods. [caption id="attachment_122812" align="alignright" width="451"] Student journalists, Matthew Hamilton from Gunn High School's Oracle, and Kai Oda from Palo Alto High School's The Campanile, take part in asking the school board candidates questions. Photo: Daniel Li[/caption] All five school board candidates gathered at the Mitchell Park Community Center for a forum hosted by Palo Alto Online. Two high school journalists, Matthew Hamilton, Gunn Oracle’s co-managing editor, and Kai Oda, co-editor-in-chief of Palo Alto High School's The Campanile, moderated the second half of the forum. The two asked the candidates questions ranging from ensuring equity at the two high schools to to supporting the continuation of teacher evaluations at the end of the semester. Still not sure who to vote for? Take a look at an introduction to each candidate and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera Melissa Baten Caswell Todd Collins Jennifer DiBrienza Heidi Emberling
excerpt: With less than 40 days remaining until election day on Nov. 8, five candidates for the Palo Alto school board are campaigning in hopes of gaining one of the three opening seats.
author: Daniel Li

title: Admin calls for safety reform after bike accident
content: [caption id="attachment_123296" align="alignnone" width="541"] Police block the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. where a car struck a Palo Alto High School student this morning. According to Principal Kim Diorio, further accidents may occur unless safety precautions are added to the dangerous intersection. "I would love to say that it [the accident] would be the last time but until we get more measures in place, who knows," Diorio said. Photo: Rachel Code.[/caption]Principal Kim Diorio is renewing her call for safety improvements at a key intersection after a driver struck a Palo Alto High School student while she biked to school at the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. this morning. According to Principal Kim Diorio, the student did not suffer any severe injuries, but EMTs took her to the hospital and she is expected to make a swift recovery. "She was then transported to the hospital, and it sounds like she is going to be ok," Diorio said. "The EMTs said that they wanted to transport her to the hospital just to make sure that everything was ok." Diorio said the driver remained with the student until paramedics and police arrived. "The driver of the vehicle stayed on scene and police and paramedics were called," Diorio said. "Police helped block Churchill while the Emergency Medical Technicians responded to the student." According to Diorio, she has always deemed the intersection unsafe. "I often feel like it's [the intersection] just an accident waiting to happen given the number of bikes crossing and the people in a rush," Diorio said. To increase the safety of students at the Churchill crossing, Diorio said the placement of a crossing guard next to the intersection will help keep drivers alert and prevent further accidents. "I feel really strongly that we should have a crossing guard at the Churchill and Castilleja intersection," Diorio said. "I've asked for the district to help provide the funding for that." Despite the frequent request from Diorio, the city has not yet come to a decision. Diorio said that the city is working on making the intersection safer. "I know the city has done more signage and they're looking at the bike lane and that light, but a crossing guard would be my hope," Diorio said.
excerpt: Principal Kim Diorio is renewing her call for safety improvements at a key intersection after a driver struck a Palo Alto High School student while she biked to school at the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. this morning.
author: Noah Yuen

title: Featured Athlete: Runner Kent Slaney
content: Imagine: A six-year-old Kent Slaney dashes through the Escondido Elementary School playground, leaving his playmates in the dust. Breezing through the dreaded mile runs in P.E., and finishing just in time for a nap and his favorite Jamba Juice. Flash to today, Slaney is a key member of both the Palo Alto High School cross country and track and field teams, amazing his community and consistently breaks personal and course records. According to Senior Kent Slaney, he discovered running at a very young age, but credits his original involvement in the sport to Jamba Juice gift cards. "I started running with Escondido jogging club," Slaney said. "They were giving out Jamba Juice gifts cards, so I wanted one of those. I then started my first race, and things kept going from there." According to Slaney, no one in his family had ever been runner, and his sudden growing interest in running gave his parents the idea of signing him up for his first race. He hasn't looked back since. "My parents did that first race with me, but after that I was on my own and just enjoyed running." Slaney said. "I did it whenever I could." As a freshman, Kent Slaney broke three season records, landing him in the top 50 running times. As a sophomore, he broke two, and another in junior year at the Lowell invitational. If one were to look at his stats, they would see consistent broken personal records at nearly every cross country meet. Cross country has a unique point system. The five fastest runners from each team to cross the finish line receive the points that correspond to their place. The first place runner receives one point, the second place runner two, and so on. The team receiving the lowest score wins, according to Capo Valley's Cross Country guide. Kent recounts the latest invitational and remarks on the teams performance as a whole. "So far it's been pretty spectacular, both as a team and individually," Slaney said. "At [the] Lowell [Invitational] we did great as a team. We got 41 points, and the next best team got 91. Also, in our first scrimmage with Gunn [High School], I broke a course record by 11 seconds. Looks like it's going to be a really great season," Slaney said. Each meet has its own set of records from past competitors. Slaney broke a course record for a meet against Gunn, with a time of 10:13 on a 2.2 mile course. Most recently, he has bested his past miles times with his new personal record of 4 minutes and 16.63 seconds, according to his CA Cross Country Profile. But Slaney is more than just a cross country star; he aspires to pursue a career in STEM. "I want to major in computer science or electrical engineering," Slaney said. "I enjoy programming a lot, I'd enjoy going into that field. I'm also looking into recruitment options, and have been balancing running with academics." Kent encourages everyone to give running a try. "Running is something that when you put your effort into it, you enjoy it so much. You go out with all the problems in the world, and come back and none of them will matter."
excerpt: Imagine: A six-year-old Kent Slaney dashes through the Escondido Elementary School playground, leaving his playmates in the dust. Flash to today, Slaney is a key member of both the Palo Alto High School cross country and track and field teams. He amazes his community and consistently breaks personal and course records.
author: Bianca Al-Shamari

title: Liveblog: First Presidential debate
content:
Presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump will face off in the 2016 election's first debate tonight at Hofstra University. Tune in at 6 p.m. for The Paly Voice's liveblog of the debate.
7:42 p.m. Thanks for tuning in to The Paly Voice's liveblog of this debate! 7:41 p.m. The debate is coming to a conclusion. The candidates' comments on security, racial tensions and international affairs were certainly illuminating — and entertaining. 7:40 p.m. "This was not a normal political event," says an NBC political commenter. 7:39 p.m. Holt's last question to the candidates is whether they will accept the outcome of the election, whoever wins. "I support our democracy," Clinton says. "I want to make America great again," Trump says. He discusses illegal immigration problems in America. 7:37 p.m. "She's [Clinton's] spent hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads on me, and many of them are untrue," Trump says. 7:35 p.m. Clinton cites her travels to 112 countries and her many actions as Secretary of State to prove her "stamina." 7:33 p.m. Clinton laughs noiselessly at Trump as he states she does not have the stamina to be president. 7:32 p.m. "We can not be the policeman of the world," Trump says. 7:32 p.m. According to Politifact, Trump overstated how much control inaina has over North Korea. 7:31 p.m. Clinton implies she will continue to support countries such as Germany and Japan--Even if they refuse to repay the US. 7:29 p.m. "We are not keeping up with other countries," Trump says on America's military tools. Trump says the Iran Deal was one of the worst deals he has ever seen. 7:27 p.m. According to Politifact, Clinton is correct that the Iran Nuclear Deal put the lid on Iran’s nuclear program without violence. 7:24 p.m. Clinton says she spent a year forming a coalition with countries including China and Russia to put tough sanctions on Iran. 7:23 p.m. "I have much better judgment and temperament than she [Clinton] does," Trump says. 7:21 p.m. Clinton appears to be having a real hoot listening to Trump's claims on the Iraq War. 7:20 p.m. Holt and Trump disagree over whether Trump originally supported the Iraq War. 7:19 p.m. Many of the 28 North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries do not spend enough of their GDP on military purposes, Trump says. However, he says he supports NATO overall. 7:17 p.m. Clinton, instead of directly answering Holt's question, praises New York for its response to 9/11. 7:15 p.m. Holt questions the candidates on how they would prevent terrorist attacks in America. Trump blames the rise of ISIS on Obama's poor withdrawel from the Middle East. While this helped lead to the rise of ISIS, the group formed in 1999 and began growing more rapidly at the start of the Iraq War in 2003. 7:13 p.m. Clinton elaborates on her plan to defeat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. "I will do everything possible to take out their leadership," Clinton said. 7:11 p.m. Trump moves the conversation to the DNC "scandal," as former DNC chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz's emails were released. "We need to get very tough on cyber-warfare," Trump said. 7:09 p.m. Trump shakes his head as Clinton accuses him of inviting Russian President Putin to hack "America." 7:08 p.m. "We're facing two different types of adversaries," Clinton says. "There are hacker groups ... but increasingly we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, or organs of states." Clinton uses Russia as an example, stating how they hacked the Democratic National Committee's emails. 7:04 p.m. "He [Trump] has really started his political activities based on this racist lie that our first black president was not an American citizen," Clinton says. "There was absolutely no evidence for it, but he persisted it year after year." Clinton said Trump was sued by the Justice Department in the 1970s for refusing to rent out homes to African Americans. 6:59 p.m. The discussion moves to President Obama's birth information. 6:57 p.m. Trump to Hillary: "No, you're wrong, you're wrong." Clinton and Trump are arguing over whether crime has dropped in New York City under the current mayor. 6:55 p.m. Trump proudly states he has the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. 6:53 p.m. Clinton champions comprehensive background checks and more gun control, especially for those on the terrorist watch list. 6:49 p.m. "No, you're wrong," says Trump to Holt on the constitutionality of the stop and risk rule. Trump says he believes in increasing the presence of law and order to reduce violence. 6:47 p.m. "We have endorsements from nearly every police group," Trump says on his campaign. He says cities like Chicago are extremely dangerous and have had thousands of shootings since early 2016. 6:46 p.m. Clinton discusses her criminal justice reform ideas. "We have to restore trust between communities and the police. We have to work to make sure our police have the best training. Everyone should respect the law and everyone should be respected by the law." 6:44 p.m. Trump discusses the success in his business ventures. What about all the bankruptcies? 6:41 p.m. According to Politifact, Trump was wrong about financial disclosures being better than tax returns. 6:38 p.m. Trump: "Our airports are like from a third world country. ... We are 20 trillion in debt and our country's a mess." 6:37 p.m. Clinton's monotonous speech makes it appear as if she has memorized her lines. 6:36 p.m. Clinton formulates several theories as to why Trump won't release his tax returns: he is not as charitable as he wants you to believe, he is not as rich as he says he is, he owes 350 million dollars to foreign banks and Wall Street or he pays nothing in taxes. 6:34 p.m. The crowd cheers as Trump says he will release his tax returns when Clinton releases her 33,000 deleted emails. Holt has to remind the crowd to remain silent. 6:33 p.m. Trump promises to eventually release his tax returns. "When we have a country thats doing so badly, thats getting ripped off by every other country..." Trump tends to not finish his sentences. 6:31 p.m. "We are in a big, fat, ugly bubble," Trump says. He really loves his adjectives! 6:30 p.m. Clinton champions making college debt-free and eradicating advantages of the top 1 percent. 6:29 p.m. "I have a feeling that by the end of this debate, I'll be blamed for everything," Clinton says. Trump interrupts Clinton's two minutes, deriding her job proposals. 6:27 p.m. "I'm calling for new jobs. ... The wealthy will create tremendous jobs [with tax cuts]," Trump says. 6:25 p.m. According to Politifact, Trump is correct in saying that Clinton flip-flopped on her support of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. 6:23 p.m. Clinton employs shameless self-promotion of her own book. 6:23 p.m. "Donald, I know you live in your own reality," Clinton says. Ouch. 6:22 p.m. "NAFTA [North American Free Trade Agreement] was one of the worst things to ever happen to the manufacturing industry," Trump says on the agreement Bill Clinton supported. 6:20 p.m. Hillary Clinton commends the job and manufacturing growth during her husband's presidency. 6:19 p.m. "I'm a great believer in all forms of energy ... but our energy policies are a disaster. Our country is losing so much in terms of energy and paying off its debt," Trump says on his energy policy. According to Trump, President Barack Obama has doubled America's level of debt. 6:17 p.m. "We would lose three and a half million jobs and maybe have another recession" if Trump's economic plans are passed, according to Clinton. 6:15 p.m. According to Politifact, Trump's tax-alleviating plan would benefit the top 0.1% more than the bottom 60%. 6:14 p.m. "I want you [Clinton] to be happy. It's very important to me," says Trump. Trump is spending a lot of time complaining about foreign countries. 6:12 p.m. Hillary Clinton says that Trump believes helping wealthy people will benefit all, but she disagrees. Clinton also highlights her goal of reducing income inequality, rewarding work rather than transactions and investing in the middle class. 6:11 p.m. "Our jobs are fleeing the country. They are going to Mexico, they are going to other countries. ... They are using our country as a piggy bank to rebuilt China and many other countries are doing the same thing. we are losing out good jobs. ... Ford is leaving, this small car division. Thousands of jobs leaving Michigan, Ohio, they're all leaving and we can't allow it to happen anymore. We have to stop our jobs from being stolen from us." He plans on reducing taxes from 35 percent to 15 percent for corporations. 6:08 p.m. "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we want to built together," Clinton says. Trump continues to scowl as Clinton speaks. 6:04 p.m. The two candidates are entering the stage. 6:04 p.m. Achieving prosperity, America's direction, and securing America will be the three topics discussed tonight. 6:03 p.m. "Her [Hillary Clinton's] need is to relate to people, especially those millennial voters," says a reporter. 6:01 p.m. Lester Holt, a registered Republican, will be moderating this debate. 5:57 p.m. National Broadcasting Company states that to Trump's podium is 10 inches taller than Clinton's to make up for the height difference.
excerpt: Presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump will face off in the 2016 election’s first debate tonight at Hofstra University. Tune in at 6 p.m. for The more »
author: Aidan Maese-Czeropski

title: Madrono staff to hold free senior portrait sessions
content: The Madrono staff is holding several photo-taking sessions for all seniors seeking free portraits. The photo sessions will take place on the Quad next week during Tutorial, Advisory and sixth period. Seniors are also permitted to hire professional photographers or take their own portraits. Previously, students were only allowed to choose from several professional photographers if they chose not to attend a free portrait-taking session. “Anyone can take senior portraits — students, professional photographers [and] siblings,” Madrono Editor-in-Chief senior Jacqueline Moore said. “As long as you have a relatively good camera, you can take your own portrait.” Portrait guidelines will remain unchanged from last year. Seniors must be the main focus of the photo, wear appropriate clothing and have an unobscured face. “It [the photo session] is a great thing, especially for those who don’t want to go out of their way to find a photographer,” senior Isaac Satz said. “It provides a service that is necessary, because everyone should have a yearbook portrait, so I’m really happy that the school has this program and I’m definitely going to make use of it.” Portraits are due to Madrono adviser Brian Wilson on a flash drive. They must be turned into Media Arts Center room 104 by Oct. 13. Both senior quotes and portraits are due on Oct. 13 and a baby ad workshop will take place Oct. 6 in MAC 104 from 12:30 to 5 p.m.  More information about dates and photo restrictions can be found on the Madrono website or Facebook page.
excerpt: The Madrono staff is holding several photo-taking sessions for all seniors seeking free portraits. The photo sessions will take place on the Quad next week during Tutorial, Advisory and sixth period.
author: Adrienne Kwok

title: Vikings conquer Santa Clara despite injuries
content: [caption id="attachment_123105" align="alignnone" width="600"] Junior running back Paul Jackson III breaks through the Santa Clara High School defense Friday night during a home football game at the Palo Alto High School stadium.  According to Jackson, the team's quick recovery from mistakes was a key factor in their victory. "We had a lot of mistakes though I think we bounced back and adjusted well," Jackson said.  Photo: Adee Newman[/caption] A solid running game combined with fierce offensive pressure allowed the Palo Alto High School football team (2-3, 1-0) to make up for the absence of key players and to defeat the Santa Clara High School Bruins (2-3, 0-1), 44-31, Friday night at the Viking Stadium. The Vikings played a great game, and they put up 44 points despite losing multiple scoring opportunities by turning the ball over. Many important players were out due to injuries. Among them were high performing members of the team, such as senior quarterback Jordan Schilling. Junior running backs Paul Jackson III and Sione Latu were crucial for Paly's success, each scoring two touchdowns and providing consistent offensive pressure throughout the game. Jackson III said that the Vikings' hard-working offensive line propelled the team to victory. "I had so much confidence in them [the offensive line] today," Jackson said. "They've been working hard all week and I may not always play the best but they definitely are the stars." Viking assistant coach Jack Schweitzer said the team would be focusing on executing the fundamentals and on avoiding costly errors. "To be honest we wanted to play a really clean game," Schweitzer said. "We wanted to play mistake free and for us it was executing what our base offense was and just getting back to some of what we like to do." According to Schweitzer, although many excellent Vikings were injured, getting some of the less-experienced players out on the field will only benefit the team overall. "It's kind of cliché, but it's like next man up," Schweitzer said. "It's unfortunate that we have some guys injured, but the nice thing is that a lot of these guys that are injured we expect to have back so getting some other guys playing time should only help us in the long run." Despite a strong offensive showing, the Vikings struggled to keep possession of the football, accumulating six turnovers over the course of the game. "At times we were successful, but obviously we turned the ball over six times, we didn't do exactly what we wanted all the time," Schweitzer said. According to Schweitzer, the team will avoid possession mistakes by adjusting their mental game. "A lot of the turnovers are just a mindset problem," Schweitzer said. "It's just putting it [keeping possession] in these guys' [the offense's] heads and emphasizing it every day." The Vikings look to take home another victory in two weeks against Saratoga High School at Paly.
excerpt: A solid running game combined with fierce offensive pressure allowed the Palo Alto High School football team (2-3, 1-0) to make up for the absence of key players and to defeat the Santa Clara High School Bruins (2-3, 0-1), 44-31, Friday night at the Viking Stadium.
author: William Sallomi

title: Online homework becomes an official part of math curriculums
content: Algebra 2 and Intro to Analysis and Calculus teachers are making MathXL for school, an online math homework program, an official part of their curriculum for the 2016-17 school year. After running MathXL as a pilot program last year, math teacher Sharla May advocated for the program to replace normal homework. [caption id="attachment_122765" align="alignright" width="429"] Junior Claire Lin completes her math homework on MathXLForSchool during flex. Photo by: Daniella Maydan[/caption] “Last fall, I asked if I could pilot the use of MathXL in my Algebra 2, and by second semester, math teacher Natalie Docktor and I were both interested in expanding the pilot to our IAC classes,” May said. “MathXL for School is now the official homework platform for all Algebra 2 and IAC classes this year. Ideally, students work the problems on paper, as they would if they copied the problems from the book. The difference is that they submit their answers online to check, rather than turn in the paper.” According to Docktor, students are given three tries to get a problem correct. There is also the option to use up one of their three tries to view the correct way to solve a problem. After each incorrect try, the program shows step-by-step instructions on how the student should have solved the problem. While students must complete all of the assigned problems, they only have to get 80 percent of the questions correct for them to receive full credit for the assignment. Additionally,  If students receive less than 80 percent, they can choose to do additional problems until their percent accuracy rises to 80 percent, meaning that it is always possible for students to receive full credit on their homework assignments, according to May. According to May, a big advantage to completing homework through MathXL is that the program provides instant feedback. “Traditional homework is scored based on completeness and the accuracy of two problems, and the turnaround for feedback was about two class periods, on average,” May said. “Unlike traditionally scored homework assignments, each problem in MathXL is scored as it is submitted and feedback about errors is also given. Another pro is that it is directly correlated to the textbook, and since it is produced by the textbook’s publisher, the problems mirror the exercises in the book.” Junior Alexander Juncosa appreciates the convenience of using MathXL instead of paper homework. “I like this a lot more because it is convenient that you can access your homework at any time or place, just as long as you have a computer," Juncosa said. "This way, you can never lose your homework or forget it at home." While junior Claire Lin prefers the on-paper homework to online homework, she appreciates the fact that MathXL provides students with example problems. “If I am stuck on a problem the program has similar example problems and they give you step-by-step instructions on how to solve them,” Lin said. “The program’s example problems are super helpful, especially if you aren’t super strong on solving a particular type of problem.” Despite its upsides, May and many of the students favor certain aspects of the paper homework.  According to May, the largest downside to MathXL is that there may be certain types of problems that are not given through MathXL. “Not every question in the textbook has an accompanying problem in the MathXL system, so some problems I may want to assign aren’t available—such problems would be used as warm-ups or in-class practice,” May said. Junior Kelsey Lu finds that it is harder to learn when completing math problems online. “When you are writing on paper, it enforces organization," Lu said. "It really helps when you want to take a step back. So if you don’t understand what you are doing wrong, writing your homework on paper allows you to go back and look at all of your steps to figure out where you went wrong. I also prefer it when a teacher checks over my work, because on MathXLForSchool you can do something wrong but still get the correct answer and then you will never find out that you didn’t understand the concept.” Despite being made an official part of the Algebra 2 and IAC curriculums, May says that the program’s effect on student performance is not yet clear.  “Looking at data from some chapter tests, there did not seem to be a significant difference in test scores for students who used the textbook versus those who used MathXL in the IAC classes,” May said. “However, I did see a significant difference in my Algebra 2 students’ test scores.  However, another variable in that Algebra 2 difference was whether the students did homework, or not. We will be able to make comparisons of last year versus this year’s test scores from Ch. 2 on up.”
excerpt: Algebra 2 and Intro to Analysis and Calculus are officially introducing MathXLForSchool, an online math homework program, into their curriculum. After running MathXL as a pilot program last year, math teacher Sharla May advocated for the program to replace normal homework.
author: Daniella Maydan
